trans-unit.target: One approach is to have one table entity per hour, with each entity representing a specific hour and storing the CPU usage for that hour.

trans-unit.source: To plot this data, the application needs to retrieve the entities holding the data from the 24 most recent hours.
trans-unit.target: To plot this data, the application needs to retrieve the entities holding the data from the 24 most recent hours.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, your application could store the CPU usage for each hour as a separate property of a single entity: to update each hour, your application can use a single InsertOrMerge Upsert call to update the value for the most recent hour.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, your application could store the CPU usage for each hour as a separate property of a single entity: to update each hour, your application can use a single InsertOrMerge Upsert call to update the value for the most recent hour.

trans-unit.source: To plot the data, the application only needs to retrieve a single entity instead of 24, making for a very efficient query (see above discussion on <linkText>query scope</linkText><title></title>).
trans-unit.target: To plot the data, the application only needs to retrieve a single entity instead of 24, making for a very efficient query (see above discussion on <linkText>query scope</linkText><title></title>).

trans-unit.source: Sometimes structured data feels like it should go in tables, but ranges of entities are always retrieved together and can be batch inserted.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes structured data feels like it should go in tables, but ranges of entities are always retrieved together and can be batch inserted.

trans-unit.source: A good example of this is a log file.
trans-unit.target: A good example of this is a log file.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you can batch several minutes of logs, insert them, and then you are always retrieving several minutes of logs at a time as well.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you can batch several minutes of logs, insert them, and then you are always retrieving several minutes of logs at a time as well.

trans-unit.source: In this case, for performance, it’s better to use blobs instead of tables, since you can significantly reduce the number of objects written/returned, as well as usually the number of requests that need made.
trans-unit.target: In this case, for performance, it’s better to use blobs instead of tables, since you can significantly reduce the number of objects written/returned, as well as usually the number of requests that need made.

trans-unit.source: A single queue can process approximately 2,000 messages (1KB each) per second (each AddMessage, GetMessage, and DeleteMessage count as a message here).
trans-unit.target: A single queue can process approximately 2,000 messages (1KB each) per second (each AddMessage, GetMessage, and DeleteMessage count as a message here).

trans-unit.source: If this is insufficient for your application, you should use multiple queues and spread the messages across them.
trans-unit.target: If this is insufficient for your application, you should use multiple queues and spread the messages across them.

trans-unit.source: You can view the current scalability targets on the page <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: You can view the current scalability targets on the page <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: See the section on table configuration that discusses the Nagle algorithm — the Nagle algorithm is generally bad for the performance of queue requests, and you should disable it.
trans-unit.target: See the section on table configuration that discusses the Nagle algorithm — the Nagle algorithm is generally bad for the performance of queue requests, and you should disable it.

trans-unit.source: Queue performance and scalability decreases as message size increases.
trans-unit.target: Queue performance and scalability decreases as message size increases.

trans-unit.source: You should place only the information the receiver needs in a message.
trans-unit.target: You should place only the information the receiver needs in a message.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve up to 32 messages from a queue in a single operation.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve up to 32 messages from a queue in a single operation.

trans-unit.source: This can reduce the number of roundtrips from the client application, which is especially useful for environments, such as mobile devices, with high latency.
trans-unit.target: This can reduce the number of roundtrips from the client application, which is especially useful for environments, such as mobile devices, with high latency.

trans-unit.source: Most applications poll for messages from a queue, which can be one of the largest sources of transactions for that application.
trans-unit.target: Most applications poll for messages from a queue, which can be one of the largest sources of transactions for that application.

trans-unit.source: Select your polling interval wisely: polling too frequently could cause your application to approach the scalability targets for the queue.
trans-unit.target: Select your polling interval wisely: polling too frequently could cause your application to approach the scalability targets for the queue.

trans-unit.source: However, at 200,000 transactions for $0.01 (at the time of writing), a single processor polling once every second for a month would cost less than 15 cents so cost is not typically a factor that affects your choice of polling interval.
trans-unit.target: However, at 200,000 transactions for $0.01 (at the time of writing), a single processor polling once every second for a month would cost less than 15 cents so cost is not typically a factor that affects your choice of polling interval.

trans-unit.source: For up to date cost information, see <linkText>Storage Pricing Details</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For up to date cost information, see <linkText>Storage Pricing Details</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can use UpdateMessage to increase the invisibility timeout or to update state information of a message.
trans-unit.target: You can use UpdateMessage to increase the invisibility timeout or to update state information of a message.

trans-unit.source: While this is powerful, remember that each UpdateMessage operation counts towards the scalability target.
trans-unit.target: While this is powerful, remember that each UpdateMessage operation counts towards the scalability target.

trans-unit.source: However, this can be a much more efficient approach than having a workflow that passes a job from one queue to the next, as each step of the job is completed.
trans-unit.target: However, this can be a much more efficient approach than having a workflow that passes a job from one queue to the next, as each step of the job is completed.

trans-unit.source: Using the UpdateMessage operation allows your application to save the job state to the message and then continue working, instead of re-queuing the message for the next step of the job every time a step completes.
trans-unit.target: Using the UpdateMessage operation allows your application to save the job state to the message and then continue working, instead of re-queuing the message for the next step of the job every time a step completes.

trans-unit.source: You should use queues to make your application architecture scalable.
trans-unit.target: You should use queues to make your application architecture scalable.

trans-unit.source: The following lists some ways you can use queues to make your application more scalable:
trans-unit.target: The following lists some ways you can use queues to make your application more scalable:

trans-unit.source: You can use queues to create backlogs of work for processing and smooth out workloads in your application.
trans-unit.target: You can use queues to create backlogs of work for processing and smooth out workloads in your application.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could queue up requests from users to perform processor intensive work such as resizing uploaded images.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could queue up requests from users to perform processor intensive work such as resizing uploaded images.

trans-unit.source: You can use queues to decouple parts of your application so that you can scale them independently.
trans-unit.target: You can use queues to decouple parts of your application so that you can scale them independently.

trans-unit.source: For example, a web front-end could place survey results from users into a queue for later analysis and storage.
trans-unit.target: For example, a web front-end could place survey results from users into a queue for later analysis and storage.

trans-unit.source: You could add more worker role instances to process the queue data as required.
trans-unit.target: You could add more worker role instances to process the queue data as required.

trans-unit.source: This article discussed some of the most common, proven practices for optimizing performance when using Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: This article discussed some of the most common, proven practices for optimizing performance when using Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: We encourage every application developer to assess their application against each of the above practices and consider acting on the recommendations to get great performance for their applications that use Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: We encourage every application developer to assess their application against each of the above practices and consider acting on the recommendations to get great performance for their applications that use Azure Storage.
